briefdescription.para: In multiplot mode, the supertitle appears above all other axis titles.
The array of JSL::Axis objects containing the relevant plot data.
The temporary directory name created for this gnuplot object.
The current x position of the axis in focus.
The current y position of the axis in focus.
The maximum permitted value of gnuplot::axis_x.
The maximum permitted value of gnuplot::axis_y.
The current number of axes on the figure.
The current gnuplot terminal mode. See gnuplot documentation for more details.
The current output file that gnuplot will try to save to, if the terminal permits it. If set to null, this argument is ignored.
The current global font used by the terminal.
< The global font size, which is used unless otherwise specified by a SetFontSize call

detaileddescription.para: The font size assigned to gnuplot::superTitle. If < 0, uses the value of gnuplot::globalFontSize

briefdescription.para: Toggle indicating that gnuplot::WindowSize() has not been called needed because changing window size is gross in gnuplot, so best left alone!
Current value of the window Width.
Current value of the window height.
Constructor function, generates a unique name for itself, and creates a directory into which it stores its own data.
Custom destructor which also calls CleanupTempFiles, tidying up after itself.
Puts gnuplot into multiplot mode, with yCount rows and xCount columns. Whenever this function is called, the entire set of axes is wiped clean.

Sets the current axis focus to the y-th row and x-th column. The "axis in focus" is acted upon whenever the gnuplot object is given a command (i.e. gnuplot::Plot) which does not otherwise specify the axis. By "switching focus", calling gnuplot::Plot will write on different axes. It is also possible to act on the axes directly, using the operator[] overload, i.e. gnuplot[i][j].Plot() would produce the same output as gnuplot.SetAxis(i,j); Plot() - though with the second version, a subsequent call to Scatter() would be written to the same axis, which would not be guaranteed for the first case.

memberdef.argsstring: (unsigned int y, unsigned int x, unsigned int ySpan, unsigned int xSpan)
memberdef.name: SetAxis

briefdescription.para: Allows one to alter the span of the axis when indexing into it, so different axes can have different sizes on the canvas. Note that this enforces a strict lock on where grids can be put - there must be enough room on the existing grid, and the span units are measured in units of these base-axis cells.

parameterdescription.para: The y coordinate of the chosen axis (0 indexed, with (0,0) being top left)
The x cooridnate of the chosen axis (0 indexed, with (0,0) being top left)
the height of the chosen axis in grid cells. Larger values push the bottom of the axis further down whilst keeping the top edge fixed.
the width of the chosen axis in grid cells. Larger values push the right hand size of the axis further right, whilst keeping the left edge fixed.

briefdescription.para: Sets the current axis focus to the idx-th axis, numbering columns-then-rows.

memberdef.argsstring: (const std::vector< T > &x, const std::vector< S > &y, NameValuePair< Ts >... args)
memberdef.name: Plot

briefdescription.para: Passes the arguments along to the Axis::Plot() function associated with the current axis focus.

briefdescription.para: The key function - until this function is called, the plot is hypothetical. Calling this function generates a gnuplot script file, which each axis writes to to generate the appropriate plot, which is then called using a system command, producing the plot.
Allows indexing into the Axes without using the SetAxis(int,int) function, accessing the Axis object directly. Note that this returns a vector of axis objects, hence access must be via gunplot[i][j].

briefdescription.para: Sets the fontsize of one of the texts associated with either the global fonts (such as global default or supertitle), or of the axis currently in focus.

parameterdescription.para: The identifier of the text to be changed

briefdescription.para: When called, and if the relevant compiler flag is not set, recursively deletes the directory associated with gnuplot::DirName.
Prints a default message and begins the setup of the gnuplot script.

parameterdescription.para: the name of the gnuplot script

briefdescription.para: Writes the data associated with the multiplot information to file.

The global interface for the plotting system. All calls should be piped through this individual class. Each gnuplot object corresponds to a single plot (though they might have severable axes within each plot)
